article.paragraph: Aleksandar ivojinovi,Post-nominalsCANOC(born August 27, 1953), better known by his stage nameAlex Lifeson, is aCanadianmusician, best known as the guitarist of the Canadian rock bandRush (band)Rush. In 1968, Lifeson co-founded the band that would become Rush, with drummerJohn Rutseyand bassist and singerJeff Jones (musician)Jeff Jones. Jones was replaced byGeddy Leea month later, and Rutsey was replaced byNeil Peartin 1974; the band's lineup has remained the same ever since.

With Rush, Lifeson plays electric and acoustic guitars, as well as otherstringed instrumentssuch asmandola,mandolin, andbouzouki. He also performs backing vocals in live performances, and occasionally plays keyboards and bass pedal synthesizers. Like the other members of Rush, Lifeson performs real-time on-stage triggering ofSampler (musical instrument)sampledinstruments, concurrently with his guitar playing.cite webhttp://www.onstagemag.com/ar/performance_rush_rolls_again/index.htmOnstagemag.comOnstagemag.com2014-07-15

The bulk of Lifeson's work in music has been with Rush, although Lifeson has contributed to a body of work outside of the band as well. Aside from music, Lifeson is part-owner ofThe Orbit Room, a bar and restaurant located inToronto, Canada, a painter, and a licensed aircraftAviatorpilot.cite webAlex Lifeson Biographyhttp://www.2112.net/xanadu/2112.netSeptember 20, 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20071012161412/http://2112.net/xanadu/October 12, 2007no

Along with his bandmatesGeddy LeeandNeil Peart, Lifeson was made an Officer of theOrder of Canadaon May 9, 1996. The trio was the first rock band to be so honoured, as a group.cite webhttp://www.maplemusic.com/artists/rus/bio.aspRUSH BiographyMaplemusic.com2014-07-15

Lifeson was ranked 98th onRolling Stone's list of the 100 greatest guitarists of all time, and third (afterEddie Van HalenandBrian May) in aGuitar Worldreaders poll also listing the 100 greatest guitarists.Citation neededSeptember 2015
article.heading: Biography
Early life
article.paragraph: Lifeson was born as Aleksandar ivojinovi inFernie, British ColumbiaFernie,British Columbia, toSerbsSerbianimmigrants, Nenad and Melanija Zivojinovich (fromSerbian languageSerbian: ,ivojinovi), and raised in Toronto,Ontario.His assumed stage name of "Lifeson" is a semi-literal translation of the name "Zivojinovich", which means "son of life" in Serbian.Horizon to HorizonRob Pagano's Rush Music TributeAccessed October 7, 2007His first exposure to formal music training came in the form of theviola, which he renounced for the guitar at the age of 12. His first guitar was a Christmas gift from his father, a six-string Kent classical acoustic which was later upgraded to an electric Japanese model. During his adolescent years, he was influenced primarily byJimi Hendrix,Pete Townshend,Jeff Beck,Eric Clapton,Jimmy Page,Alex Lifeson profileEpiphoneAccessed March 31, 2006Steve HackettandAllan Holdsworth;Guitar World Staff (2012-01-12). "60 Minutes with Alex Lifeson and Geddy Lee of Rush".Guitar Player.New Bay Media. Retrieved 2012-02-04.he explained in 2011 that "Clapton's solos seemed a little easier and more approachable. I remember sitting at my record player and moving the needle back and forth to get the solo in 'Spoonful.' But there was nothing I could do with Hendrix."cite newsAlex Lifeson: Rush Keeps Rollin'CohenElliot StephenSeptember 2011[[Vintage Guitar (magazine)|Vintage Guitar]]42–44August 28, 2013http://www.2112.net/powerwindows/transcripts/20110900vintageguitar.htmIn 1963 Lifeson met future Rush drummerJohn Rutseyin school. Both interested in music, they decided to form a band. Lifeson was primarily a self-taught guitarist with the only formal instruction coming from a high school friend in 1971 who taught classical guitar lessons. This training lasted for roughly a year and a half.
Lifeson recalls what inspired him to play guitar in a 2008 interview:

paragraph.template: quote<arg name="My brother-in-law played flamenco guitar. He lent his guitar to me and I grew to like it. When you're a kid, you don't want to play an accordion because it would be too boring. But your parents might want you to play one, especially if you're from a Yugoslavian family like me.{{cite journal|title">Inquirer with Alex Lifeson|author

article.paragraph: Lifeson's first girlfriend, Charlene, gave birth to their eldest son, Justin, in October 1970, and they married in 1975. Their second son, Adrian, was born two years later. Adrian is also involved in music, and performed on two tracks from Lifeson's 1996 solo project,Victor.
article.heading: Rush
article.paragraph: Image:20110527-200145 Rush Ahoy Rotterdam 1200x0800.jpgrightthumb240pxAlex Lifeson during the 20102011Time Machine Tour, Ahoy,Rotterdam, The Netherlands (May 27, 2011)Lifeson's neighbourJohn Rutseybegan experimenting on a rented drum kit. In 1963, Lifeson and Rutsey formed The Projection, which eventually became Rush in August 1968 following the recruitment of original bassist and vocalistJeff Jones (musician)Jeff Jones.Geddy Lee, ahigh schoolfriend of Lifeson's, assumed this role soon after.cite bookBanasiewiczBillRush Visions: The Official BiographyOmnibus Press19900-7119-1162-2

Instrumentally, Lifeson is renowned for his signature riffing, electronic effects and processing, unorthodox chord structures, and the copious arsenal of equipment he has used over the years.Alex Lifeson profileDinosaur Rock GodAccessed March 31, 2006Alex Lifeson minor overviewGuitar PlayerAccessed July 16, 2007Alex Lifeson ArchiveAlex Lifeson Archive and equipmentAccessed July 16, 2007

Rush was on hiatus for several years starting in 1997 owing toGhost Rider: Travels on the Healing Roadpersonal tragedies in Neil Peart's life, and Lifeson had not picked up a guitar for at least a year following those events.cite journalHammondShawnBack in the limelight: Alex Lifeson and Rush reignite after a five-year hiatusGuitar Player388August 2002New Bay MediaHowever, after some work in his home studio and on various side projects, Lifeson returned to the studio with Rush to begin work on 2002'sVapor Trails.Vapor Trailsis the first Rush album since the 1970s to lack keyboardsas such, Lifeson used over 50 different guitars in whatShawn HammondofGuitar Playercalled "his most rabid and experimental playing ever." Geddy Lee was amenable to leaving keyboards off the album due in part to Lifeson's ongoing concern about their use. Lifeson's approach to the guitar tracks for the album eschewed traditional guitar riffs and solos in favour of "tonality and harmonic quality."
During live performances, he is still responsible for cuing various guitar effects, the use of bass pedal synthesizers, and backing vocals.

While the bulk of Lifeson's work in music has been with Rush, Lifeson's first major outside work was his solo project,Victor (album)Victor, released in 1996.Victorwas attributed as a self-titled work (i.e.Victoris attributed as theartistas well as thealbum title). This was done deliberately as an alternative to issuing the album explicitly under Lifeson's name. The title track is from theW.H. Audenpoem, also entitled "Victor". Both son Adrian and wife Charlene also contributed to the album. A follow-up album, possibly including vocals bySarah McLachlan, was rumored in the late 1990s, but was apparently shelved due to Atlantic Records' lack of support for the first album.cite webEric Hansenhttp://www.2112.net/powerwindows/main/VIClyrics.htmAlex Lifeson's "Victor" linernotes and lyrics from Power Windows2112.net2014-07-15
article.heading: Side projects
article.paragraph: Lifeson has also contributed to a body of work outside of his involvement with the band in the form of instrumental contributions to other musical outfits. He made a guest appearance on the 1985Platinum Blonde (band)Platinum BlondealbumAlien Shoresperforming guitar solos on the songs "Crying Over You" and "Holy Water". Later, in 1990, he appeared onLawrence Gowan's album,Lost Brotherhoodto play guitar. In 1995, he guested on two tracks onTom Cochrane'sRagged Ass Roadalbum and then in 1996 onI Mother Earth's "Like a Girl" from theScenery and Fishalbum. In 1997 he appeared on theMerry Axemas: A Guitar Christmasalbum. Lifeson played "the Little Drummer Boy" which was released as track 9 on the album.allmusicalbummw0000463676overviewMay 23, 2013In 2006, Lifeson founded TheBig Dirty Band, which he created for the purpose of providing original soundtrack material forTrailer Park Boys: The Movie. LifesonJam sessionjammedregularly with The Dexters (The Orbit Roomhouse band from 1994 to 2004). Lifeson made a guest appearance on the 2007 albumFear of a Blank Planetby UK progressive rock band,Porcupine Tree, contributing a solo during the songAnesthetize. He also appeared on the 2008 albumTiles (band)#About "Fly Paper"Fly Paperby Detroit progressive rockersTiles (band)Tiles. He plays on the track "Sacred and Mundane". Outside of band related endeavours, Lifeson composed the theme for the first season of the science-fiction TV seriesAndromeda (TV series)Andromeda. He also produced 3 songs from the albumAway from the Sunby3 Doors Down.
article.heading: Television and film appearances
article.paragraph: Lifeson made his film debut as himself under his birth name in the 1972 Canadian documentary filmCome on Children.IMDb title269104Come on Children

In a 2003 episode of the CanadianmockumentaryTrailer Park Boys, titled "Closer to the Heart", Lifeson plays a partly fictional version of himself. In the story, he is kidnapped byRobb WellsRickyand held as punishment for his inability (or refusal) to provide the main characters with free tickets to a Rush concert. In the end of the episode, Alex reconciles with the characters, and performs a duet of "Closer to the Heart" withMike Smith (actor)Bubblesat the trailer park. In 2006, Lifeson appeared inTrailer Park Boys: The Movieas a traffic cop in the opening scene and in 2009 he appeared in their follow up movie,Trailer Park Boys: Countdown to Liquor Day, as an undercover vice cop in drag.

In 2008, Lifeson and the rest of Rush played "Tom Sawyer" at the end of an episode ofThe Colbert Report. According to Colbert, this was their first appearance on American television as a band in 33 years.cite webhttp://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/176340/july-16-2008/rushRush - The Colbert Report - Video Clip | Comedy CentralColbertnation.com2008-07-162014-07-15
In 2009, he and the rest of the band appeared as themselves in the comedyI Love You, Man.Manohla Dargis,Best Man Wanted. Must Be Rush Fan,The New York Times, March 20, 2009 (accessed March 31, 2009).
Alex Lifeson appears as the border guard in the 2009 movieSuck.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1323605/fullcredits?ref_=tt_ov_st_sm

The role of Dr. Funtime inThe Drunk and On Drugs Happy Funtime Hourwas originally written with Alex Lifeson in mind, but due to scheduling conflicts the role was given toMaury Chaykininstead.Drunk and on Drugs Happy Funtime Hour: Behind the Scenes with Maury Chaykin
article.heading: The Naples incident
article.paragraph: OnNew Year's Eve#United StatesNew Year's Eve2003, Lifeson, his son, and his daughter-in-law were arrested at theRitz-Carltonhotel inNaples, Florida.waybackhttp://www.rush.com/low/viewStory.php?id20070705122031Lifeson, after intervening in an altercation between his son and police, was accused of assaulting a sheriff's deputy in what was described as a drunken brawl. In addition to suffering a broken nose at the hands of the officers, Lifeson wastasertasedsix times. His son was also tased repeatedly.

On April 21, 2005, Lifeson and his son agreed to a plea deal with the localprosecutorfor theState's Attorneyoffice to avoid jail time by pleadingnolo contendereno contestto a first-degreemisdemeanorcharge of resisting arrest without violence.cite webhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?vRush' Alex Lifeson in courtYouTube2008-06-212014-07-15As part of the plea agreement Lifeson and his son were each sentenced to 12 months of probation with the adjudication of that probation suspended. Lifeson acknowledged his subsequent legal action against both the Ritz-Carlton and the Collier County Sheriff's Office for "their incredibly discourteous, arrogant and aggressive behaviour of which I had never experienced in thirty years of travel."waybackhttp://www.rush.com/low/viewStory.php?id20070705122005Although both actions were initially dismissed in April 2007,cite webhttp://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1052834/police-cleared-in-altercation-with-rushs-lifesonPolice Cleared In Altercation With Rush's LifesonBillboard2014-07-15legal claims against the Ritz-Carlton were reinstated upon appeal, and ultimately settled out of court in August 2008, with Lifeson and his son agreeing to a confidential settlement from Ritz-Carlton.cite webAisling Swifthttp://www.naplesnews.com/news/2008/aug/22/ritz-carlton-settles-lawsuit-rush-guitarists-son/Ritz-Carlton settles lawsuit with Rush guitarist’s son - Naples Daily NewsNaplesnews.com2008-08-222014-07-15
In his journal-based bookRoadshow, Peart relates the band's perspective on the events of that New Year's Eve.
article.heading: Guitar equipment
article.paragraph: Image:Alex Lifeson.jpgRightthumb180pxAlex Lifeson playing hisGibson Les Paulin the 'Heritage Cherry Sunburst'. This guitar has been modified to incorporate aFloyd Rosetremolo.In Rush's early career, Lifeson used aGibson ES-335for the first tour, and in 1976 bought a 1974Gibson Les Paul; he used those two guitars until the late 1970s. He had aFender Stratocasterwith aBill Lawrence (guitar maker)Bill Lawrencehumbucker andFloyd Rosevibrato bridge as backup "and for a different sound."For theA Farewell to Kingssessions, Lifeson began using aGibson EDS-1275for songs like "Xanadu (Rush song)Xanadu"Citation neededJuly 2011and his main guitar became a whiteGibson ES-355.During this period Lifeson usedHiwattamplifiers.cite webhttp://www.guitarworld.com/prime-cuts-rushPrime Cuts: RushGuitar World2009-11-052014-07-15He played aGibson B series#B-45twelve-string Gibson B-45on songs like "Closer to the Heart."

From 1980 to 1986, Lifeson used four identically modified Stratocasters, all of them equipped with the Floyd Rose bridge. As a joke, he called these Hentor Sportscasters a made-up name inspired by Peter Henderson's name, who was the producer ofGrace Under Pressure (Rush album)Grace Under Pressure.waybackhttp://www.2112.net/powerwindows/GUPtourbook.htm20081224014536He also played a Gibson Howard Roberts Fusion.By 1987, Lifeson switched to Signature guitars (Canadian-made) which, while "awful to playvery uncomfortable--...had a particular sound I liked."Lifeson primarily usedPRS GuitarsPRS guitarsin the later-half of the 1990 Presto tour, and again during the recording ofRoll The Bonesin 1990/1991.Citation neededJuly 2011He would continue to play PRS for the next sixteen years through the recording and touring ofCounterparts (album)Counterparts,Test for EchoandVapor Trailsas well as the R30 tour. The last few years, he said in 2011, he has "used Gibson almost exclusively. There's nothing like having a low-slung Les Paul over my shoulder" In early 2011, Gibson introduced the "Alex Lifeson Axcess", a guitar specially designed for him. These are custom made Les Pauls with Floyd Rose systems on both of them. He mentioned the process taking two years to design a perfect guitar. He used these two custom Les Pauls on the Time Machine Tour. These guitars are also available through Gibson, in a viceroy Brown or Crimson color. Lifeson used these two guitars heavily on the tour.For the Clockwork Angels tour, Gibson built an Alex Lifeson Axcess model in black which became Lifeson's primary guitar for much of the show. For all acoustic work, he played one of his Axcess guitars using the piezo pick-ups; no acoustic guitars were used at all in the Clockwork Angels show.

In 2005, Hughes & Kettner introduced an Alex Lifeson signature series amplifier; Lifeson donates his royalties from the sale of these signature models toUNICEF.cite webTriAmp MKII Alex Lifesonhttp://www.hughes-and-kettner.com/products.php5?idHughes-and-kettner.com14 June 2012

In 2012, Lifeson abandoned his signature Triamps in favor for custom-built Lerxst OmegaMarshall AmplificationSilver Jubileeclones, handmade by Mojotone in Burgaw, NC andMesa Boogie Mark SeriesMesa/Boogie Mark Vheads. He still uses the Hughes & Kettner Coreblades.

Foreffects uniteffects, Lifeson is known to usechorus effectchorus,phase shifting, andflangerflanging. Throughout his career, he has used well-known pedals such as theElectro-HarmonixElectro-Harmonix Electric Mistressflanger, theBoss CorporationBOSS CE-1chorus, theDunlop crybabywah, among others.cite webhttp://www.dinosaurrockguitar.com/new/node/32Alex LifesonDinosaur Rock Guitar2008-05-282014-07-15
Recently, Lifeson has made his signature acoustic guitar model with Paul Reed Smith. The guitar is currently available for private stock order.

Gibson introduced an Alex Lifeson R40 Les Paul Axcess signature guitar in June 2015.http://www.rush.com/alex-lifeson-r40-les-paul-axcess/This is a limited edition with 50 guitars signed and played by Lifeson, and another 250 available without the signature.
article.heading: Other instruments played
article.paragraph: In addition to acoustic and electric guitars, Lifeson has also playedmandola,mandolinandbouzoukion recent Rush studio albums, includingTest for Echo,Vapor TrailsandSnakes & Arrows. During live Rush performances, Lifeson uses aMIDI controllerthat enables him to use his feet to trigger sounds fromsampler (musical instrument)digital samplers, without taking his hands off his guitar. (Prior to this, Lifeson usedMoog TaurusBass Pedals before they were replaced by Korg MIDI pedals in the 1980s.) Lifeson and his bandmates share a desire to accurately depict songs from their albums when playing live performances. Toward this goal, beginning in the late 1980s the band equipped their live performances with a capacious rack of samplers. The band members use these samplers in real-time to recreate the sounds of non-traditional instruments,accompaniments, vocalharmonies, and other sound "events" that are familiarly heard on the studio versions of the songs. In live performances, the band members share duties throughout most songs, with each member triggering certain sounds with his available limbs, while playing his primary instrument(s).
